competencies.name: Inquiry and Communication
competencies.description: Use Social Studies inquiry processes and skills to ask questions; gather, interpret, and analyze ideas; and communicate findings and decisions.

indicators.name: Ask relevant questions to frame historical and contemporary investigations.
Gather, interpret, and analyze information and ideas from diverse sources.
Communicate findings, interpretations, and decisions effectively.

competencies.name: Significance
competencies.description: Assess the significance of people, places, events, or developments at particular times and places, recognizing that significance varies by perspective.

indicators.name: Identify the importance of historical and contemporary people, places, or events.
Compare varying perspectives on their significance for different groups.

competencies.name: Evidence
competencies.description: Evaluate competing accounts of the past and present by investigating points of contention, reliability of sources, and adequacy of evidence, including data.

indicators.name: Assess the justification for competing historical or contemporary accounts.
Evaluate the reliability and credibility of primary and secondary sources.
Determine whether available evidence adequately supports conclusions.

competencies.name: Continuity and Change
competencies.description: Compare and contrast continuities and changes for different groups at particular times and places.

indicators.name: Identify examples of continuity and change across time.
Compare the impacts of continuity and change on different groups in society.

competencies.name: Cause and Consequence
competencies.description: Assess how underlying conditions and the actions of individuals or groups influence events, decisions, or developments, and analyze multiple consequences.

indicators.name: Analyze how conditions influenced historical and contemporary events.
Assess the role of individuals and groups in shaping outcomes.
Evaluate the intended and unintended consequences of events or decisions.

competencies.name: Perspective
competencies.description: Explain and infer different perspectives on past or present people, places, issues, or events by considering norms, values, worldviews, and beliefs.

indicators.name: Analyze different perspectives shaped by worldview and cultural context.
Interpret how norms, values, and beliefs influence perspectives.

competencies.name: Ethical Judgment
competencies.description: Make reasoned ethical judgments about actions in the past and present, and assess appropriate ways to remember and respond.

indicators.name: Evaluate the ethics of historical and contemporary actions and policies.
Make reasoned judgments about appropriate responses to past injustices.
Assess how societies should remember and respond to injustices.

contexts.name: Government and Ideologies
contexts.description: Government, First Peoples governance, political institutions, and ideologies.

contexts.name: Policies and Autonomy
contexts.description: Environmental, political, and economic policies, and the development of Canadian autonomy.

contexts.name: Canadian Identities
contexts.description: Canadian identities and their development in relation to diversity and multiculturalism.

contexts.name: Genocide and Human Rights

contexts.name: Conflicts and Cooperation
contexts.description: Domestic and international conflicts and cooperation in the 20th and 21st centuries.
